block.p: SHIPPING SOYBEANS TO CHINA -- As its appetite turns from tofu to pork, poultry and beef, China has turned to Brazil to provide it with soybeans to feed livestock. Vanishing cropland and diminishing water supplies are hampering China's ability to feed itself, changing the profile of global agricultural trade. [Page A1.]

KERKORIAN BIDS FOR CHRYSLER -- Kirk Kerkorian's investment arm, the Tracinda Corporation, made a $4.5 billion offer for the struggling Chrysler Group that hinges on winning the exclusive right to negotiate with DaimlerChrysler and a deal with the United Automobile Workers union that could mean worker concessions. [C1.]
$28 MILLION FOR 4 MONTHS' WORK -- The Ford Motor Company paid its new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, $28.18 million in his first four months on the job, the automaker said. [C6.]
STABILITY CONTROL TO BE STANDARD -- All new vehicles will be required to have antirollover technology, called electronic stability control, by the 2012 model year, the government said. [C6.]

ZELL GETS A VETO AT TRIBUNE -- The Tribune Company disclosed new details of its plan to go private in a deal engineered by the real estate tycoon Samuel Zell. Although Mr. Zell will control a minority of the board, he will have the right to veto any major transactions. [C1.]

BITTER RIVALRY GOES TO COURT -- A federal trial is about to begin over the contention that Splenda, the artificial sweetener, misleads consumers when it says it is made from sugar and is natural. The plaintiff? Splenda's rival, Equal. [C1.]

PLEA FROM CORPORATE OFFICES -- Many executives of large companies are starting to call for a national approach to fixing health care, warning that an employer-subsidized health system is unsustainable. [C1.]

FEDERAL OFFICIAL HELD STOCK -- A senior official at the federal Education Department sold more than $100,000 in shares in a student loan company even as he was helping oversee lenders in the federal student loan program. [A1.]

NEW LEADER FOR PARENT OF AIRBUS -- The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company named a new German co-chairman, tapping an aerospace engineer who also played a central role in conceiving the group's delicate management structure. [C3.]

GERMANY'S SUPERVISORY BOARDS -- An unusual law that shapes the oversight of German companies by requiring labor representation on supervisory boards is again being re-examined after corruption scandals at Siemens and Volkswagen. [C3.]

NEW THEME FOR AMERICAN EXPRESS -- American Express is making an unusually quick switch in advertising campaign themes. The current theme -- ''My life. My card.'' -- will be supplemented by one that asks the rhetorical question, ''Are you a cardmember?'' Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C3.]

CABLE NETWORKS TURN AWAY EBAY -- Turner Networks, Discovery, Lifetime, and other cable networks have decided to boycott an online exchange designed by eBay to sell advertising time, the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau said. [C3.]

A WINEMAKER'S RISING PROFIT -- Constellation Brands, the world's biggest winemaker, said its quarterly profit grew 26 percent as strong wine sales in the United States helped offset heightened competition in Britain and a drop in sales of imported beer. Earnings after paying preferred dividends climbed to $70.2 million, or 29 cents a share, from $55.8 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. [C2.]
A CHAIR IN THE BOARDROOM -- A new effort among women lawyers seeks to get more of them seats on corporate boards. [C5.]
SLIGHT GAINS END THE WEEK -- Wall Street ended a holiday-shortened week with a quiet advance as investors adjusted portfolios ahead of a three-day weekend. [C8.]
JOBLESS CLAIMS ROSE LAST WEEK -- New jobless claims rose by 11,000 last week, more than was forecast, but analysts said the labor market remained on solid ground. [C2.]
DOG BISCUITS ARE RECALLED -- A recall of tainted pet food has been widened to include dog biscuits made by Sunshine Mills, of Red Bay, Ala. [A15.]

Some of the payments at the center of Conrad M. Black's criminal fraud trial were reported to federal regulators in a timely fashion and not hidden as prosecutors have suggested, jurors were told. (REUTERS)
Qualcomm, the wireless chip developer, requested an arbitration ruling in its legal battle with the cellphone maker Nokia to resolve their dispute over a technology license agreement. (REUTERS)

Shares of Biosite Inc., a tiny maker of diagnostic tests, jumped after Inverness Medical Innovations announced that it would make an unsolicited cash offer to buy the company for $90 a share, trumping an acquisition bid from a third rival. (AP)
